CatDescriptText: Gladys Lee, housewife, Uptown and Don Knueber, salesman, Ingomar, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 3, 1960, pg. A1 with question "What is our country's most pressing domestic problem?"  Mrs. Lee's answer reads: "Money is the most pressing problem today.  There should be more jobs especially for women.  And something should be done to reduce taxes because the more you make the less you have."  Mr. Knueber's answer reads: "The most pressing domestic problem we face is that of guaranteeing the rights of our fellowman - civil rights, as some call it.  If we live by the Constitution, we should abide by it."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Gladys Lee wearing dark sun dress with thin straps, posed in front of brick building; Portrait of Don Knueber wearing dark bow tie and suit jacket, posed in front of brick building
